Lack enough support: The claim that the name of the children's game "tag" originated as the acronym of "touch and go" lacks sufficient evidence or support.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the origin of the word "tag" as an acronym is true without providing substantial evidence or historical documentation.
Contradict fact: The expert's verdict contradicts the claim by stating that the origin of the word "tag" as an acronym is not supported by any dictionaries or etymologists.
Understate: The claim understates the complexity and variations of the game of tag, suggesting that it is a simple and generic game when in fact it has numerous variations and is one of the oldest and most ubiquitous children's games.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the intuitive obviousness of the origin of the word "tag" as an acronym, implying that it should be common knowledge when there is no substantial evidence to support this.
Exist alternative explanation: The expert's verdict suggests that the origin of the word "tag" has alternative explanations, such as its unknown origin according to Merriam-Webster and the Oxford English Dictionary's statement that it originated in the mid-eighteenth century.
Falters at times: The claim falters by relying on internet memes and trivia offerings as a source of knowledge, which may not always provide accurate or reliable information.
